CatDescriptText: Mr. Eugene Dixon, welder, 170 Bonifay Street, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 10, 1959, pg. A1 with question: "How do you think Soviet Premier Khrushchev's visit to the United States affected relations between our country and Russia? Were you or were you not impressed by his visit to Pittsburgh?" answer reads: "I think that most people view Khrushchev now as being partly sincere in his speeches, and I think that Pittsburgh is the place where he showed a little more sincerity.  This was mainly because of the more wonderful welcome extended here."
TitMainTitle: Portrait of Eugene Dixon, wearing light colored cap, eyeglasses, and striped short sleeved shirt, standing on Liberty Avenue in front of Jenkins Arcade with haberdashers and store with striped awning, Downtown
